page_analysis.text_content:
Setback considerations

Easements
Some easements affect setbacks i.e., setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line as illustrated in Fig 16 on this page. Easements that affect setbacks are:
• Creek easements
• Public street easements

Note: most public utility easements do not affect setbacks.

Sidewalks
The sidewalk may not indicate the lot line. Often, the street easement or public right-of-way extends for several feet beyond the sidewalk. Fig 16 on this page illustrates this common circumstance and how the setbacks are affected i.e., they must be measured from the lot line regardless of the sidewalk.

Oddly shaped lots
For some lots, the setbacks and required yards may not be obvious . Fig 17 on page 23 indicates the appropriate site plan for lot shapes about which questions often arise:
• flag lot (Fig 17 A)
• corner lot (Fig 17 B)
• through lot (Fig 17 D)
• wedge-shaped lot (Fig 17 E)
• lot with more than four sides (Fig 17 F & G)

Flag & substandard lots
Fig 17 on page 23 also illustrates examples of setbacks that have been reduced for smaller or oddly shaped lots e.g.,
• the front setback of a flag lot (Fig 17 A)
• the street-side yard setback for substandard corner lots that are less than 50' wide (Fig 17 C)

visual_elements.description: Fig 16 Setbacks: easements and sidewalks. Diagram showing a rectangular lot with labeled areas: Rear yard, Buildable area, Front yard, and Interior-side yard on both sides. The diagram illustrates setbacks measured from the easement on the top side (with a shaded easement area labeled 'Creek or public access easement e.g., street or alley') and from the lot line on the bottom side (with a sidewalk shown). Arrows indicate that setbacks are measured from the easement regardless of lot lines on the top side, and from the lot lines regardless of sidewalk location on the bottom side. A key explains symbols: solid line for curb, dashed line for lot line, a patterned block for sidewalk, shaded area for buildable area, and diagonal lines for easement.
visual_elements.location: Right side, middle of the page

visual_elements.description: Note box with text: 'Note: For information regarding creek easements, contact the Santa Clara Valley Water District'

technical_specifications.parameter: Street-side yard setback for substandard corner lots
Space between sidewalk edge and lot line

additional_notes: Page number 22 at bottom left corner
No handwritten notes or stamps detected
cross_references: See section on Lot Size for more information about creek easements
See section on Lot Size for more information about public street easements

qualifiers.text: Some easements affect setbacks i.e., setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of the lot line
The sidewalk may not indicate the lot line
Note: most public utility easements do not affect setbacks
Note if the lot line is in the middle of the street, then the setback is measured from the edge of the public street easement or right-of-way

conditions.text: Setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of where the lot lines are located
Setbacks are measured from the lot lines regardless of where the sidewalks are located
The space between the sidewalk edge and the lot line is part of the public right of way. It may be 0' or more than 15'
The street-side yard setback for substandard corner lots that are less than 50' wide is reduced

logical_relationships.expression: Setbacks must be measured from the edge of the easement regardless of lot lines AND setbacks are measured from the lot lines regardless of sidewalks

execution_sequence.action: Determine if an easement affects the setback measurement
If sidewalks are present, measure setbacks from lot lines regardless of sidewalk location
For substandard corner lots less than 50 feet wide, apply reduced street-side yard setback
